conclusion: The upper surface AB is plane.
The two beams a and b arrive from air and are normal to AB, so at AB they are not deflected; they simply enter the glass and remain parallel.
Inside the glass each beam travels in a straight line toward the spherical lower surface.
At the spherical surface, the light goes from the denser medium (glass, index n) into the rarer medium (air, index 1).
According to the figure, the two emergent rays finally intersect at the point P situated outside the glass on the left-hand side.
In the drawing, the right-hand ray b must cross the symmetry axis and reach a point situated to the left of that axis, i.e., it turns through a larger angle than the left-hand ray a.
Therefore, the deviation of b at the spherical surface is larger than the deviation of a.
When light passes from glass (index n > 1) to air (index 1), Snell’s law gives sin i = n sin r.
For the same i, the larger the refractive index n, the larger the refraction angle r, hence the larger the total deviation from the original direction.
Because b is bent more than a, the glass must have for b a larger refractive index: nb > na.

For normal dispersion, which ordinary optical glass exhibits in the visible range, the refractive index increases with frequency (or decreases with wavelength): higher frequency → larger n → shorter wavelength in air.
Equation (2) therefore means fb > fa, λb < λa.
The “ability” of a beam to show noticeable diffraction at an opening or an obstacle is governed by the ratio λ / D (wavelength divided by the characteristic size of the aperture or obstacle).
For two beams passing the same aperture (or skimming the same obstacle), the beam with the longer wavelength diffracts more strongly.
From (3) beam b has the shorter wavelength; beam a has the longer wavelength.
Hence, under identical geometric conditions, beam a will spread (diffract) more than beam b.
The statement “Light b is more likely to exhibit diffraction than light a” is false.

Because the right-hand beam b is bent more strongly at the spherical interface, the glass has a higher refractive index for b, which means b has the higher frequency (shorter wavelength). Diffraction effects are stronger for the longer-wavelength beam a, not for b.
